I don't want to bash this movie. Trust me, I don't. It truly hurts me more than anything that I have to call this movie nothing more than some of the most gorgeous CGI ever committed to film. They are really mesmerizing and absolutely stunning. The reason I gave this movie a 1/10 however is that visuals(no matter how transcendent in their nature), do not make a movie. They make part of a movie. For this reason the movie feels in my opinion to be rushed, as if they focused completely on the graphics over the story. So basically, this is what the Star Wars prequels would look like if done by James Cameron: All special effects, and very little story and character development. Frankly, Avatar is a very powerful disappointment, and I expect better from James Cameron, who is practically legendary in his skills as a filmmaker.

Welcome to 21 century western style ...all is missing is a John Wayne avatar ... am so disappointed, oh YES, big time.CGA and 3-D effects are fabulous, like nothing one this world, but after 60 maybe 90 minutes, the magic is gone and the lack of original storyline is to conspicuous.I guest they were to much into the magics of new special effects and they just forgot to get at least a decent script. What is puzzled me is where in the woods they spend 400+ millions $, it's just beyond me, and I know software....! Probably,in the final bill they add the cleaning lady to with like 5000$/day! For 400mil.$ Cameron could almost fix a country like Haiti or East Timor and get a Nobel Price! What a waste of creative energy and money.

At first I was in awe of this movie...the special effects are amazingly real looking. It was fascinating to see another world evolve before my eyes that was filled with fawn and fauna.Then I waited for the story to begin...and that's when the let-down began. The movie is a $250 Million dollar cowboy and Indians picture. The earth mining company (the cowboys) want to kick the planet's inhabitants out (the Indians) so they can rape and pillage the land (the New World). The political agenda was so clear...Americans (or Europeans) are bad and all the natives of the countries they colonized (even if it was for the better) are good. It would have been far better to camouflage this agenda a little so it would not seem like a lecture.I was hoping the ending would justify the rest of the movie...I was wrong there too...it was quite hard to believe that bows, arrows, and animals, would easily, and rather quickly, take down a gargantuan military force

Avatar was painfully unoriginal. Sure it looks good, but I've seen this same tired worn out story 40 times during my 47 years on this planet. It is too long -- it clock in at 2 1/2 ass-numbing hours-- too boring, and it takes itself way too seriously. Not to mention the fact that there are plot holes big enough to drive a Mack truck through. I would have thought that for $300 million Cameron could have bought an original story. Instead, Avatar offers the same old worn out themes that leftist Hollywood has been cranking out since the communist infiltration back in the late 1940s. The top three reasons why I go to see a movie are ENTERTAINMENT! ENTERTAINMENT!! ENTERTAINMENT!!! Unfortunately, despite all of it's pretty bells & whistles Avatar does not deliver.

This movie has great special effects and a cool central sci-fi theme; the concept of an "avatar." 9 or 10 stars for each. But unfortunately the movie lacks any cohesive plot, has cookie-cutter characters and clich√© dialog. This lack of originality destroys what should be emotionally charged moments and creates painfully stereotyped/racist portrayals. Also, the beauty of the digital animation is undermined by uninspired cinematography. So 10 stars for animation, but everything else was below average: 3 or 4 stars each for direction, writing, cinematography, plot, etc.Overall, this is a bad movie which contains one or two precious gems: the avatar concept is wonderful fantasy, and the images are stunning.

What an incredible film! Cinematography of the a new era. Where do I start ? It seems that it's a just perfect sci-fi blockbuster that is at the same time a fairytale, a love story and a battle for survival. But it continues being a (delayed) cry for the slaughtered tribes that used to live in what is now called America or Australia, along with the deforestation and the irrational destruction of our natural environment. And last but not least, it is the 'connection' this all has with us.Watching Avatar springs into mind a perfect blending of elements and clich√©s of so many well known movies: Dancing with the Wolves, The Matrix, Born on the 4th of July and Pocahonta to name a few. But I found this to be superb! All in a future high-tech metaphora, of enormous weaponry and spaceships and a primitive jungle world that's both weird but also so familiar. Coming to the visual aspects of Avatar, I was simply awed. Its not the first Movie I've seen in 3D recently, but its certainly the best. I think that event if you remove 3D, this movie is an eye candy from start to finish. Simply amazing, but do watch it in 3D before it goes!

The visual effects in this movie are unseen and bombastic. After a wile you loose this feeling of "it is just a movie". You are immersed in the movie and you are exploring a new world. It is more than one time that you loose your breath. Beautiful images are following each other at high speed and you just can't believe what you are seeing.The story is a bit thin and predictable though there are nice character developments. But that just doesn't matter because Avatar is just more than a movie, more than a true masterpiece, it is a lifetime experience, a movie that writes film history.You have too see it in 3D, better IMAX, because the 3D images are a vital part of the movie and it is the way James Cameron intended it.

I rated this movie 3 out of 10. But it deserves at least an 8. I just wanted to protest. A nice movie, a good movie indeed. Very rugged. Flowing. I'm not being sardonic, I really liked it. But its simple, even naive. Simple characters, simple story. One less dimension in the movie, an extra dimension in script won't hurt anybody. A great opportunity wasted I guess. Many talented people, worked hard for many years. So I wanted some depth. I expected something more than a 3D action thriller. Dancing with wolves did have something fresh, something nice. Discrict 9 has xenophobia, racism, bureaucracy, cold corporate mind, and action, friendship, delicious aliens, effects and some gore. It was fresh and surprising and new. Avatar is just big, simple, nice.I love American S.F. writers. Greg Bear, Theodore Sturgeon, and many more wrote books full of hive minds, planet sized intellects, and with some solid (fictional) science background too. Hall Clement's creatures, P.K.Dicks twisted visions, U.K.le Guin's poetic depth, they are truly amazing. SF opens ones mind. Good SF is also good philosophy, good literature, and it is always good for me. They are hundreds of amazingly disturbing, mind boggling, incredible books out there, but no one dares to touch them. I guess they are too complicated. Ot they prefer not to ruin them, yet.The story is, an evil, extortionist, capitalist, militarist world company decides to rape a magical planet with good scenery, full of half naked, very long legged girls, (all of them happen to love long walks in the woods, and on the woods, paragliding and horseback riding). But handful of humans seeing the error of their ways decides to lead them to an all out war against invasion. Their strategy consist of throwing things and ramming if possible, shrieking when all else fails. Not very Clausewitzian, and it does not work. But this planet has a hive mind, an alien Gaia, (which has perverse vision of evolution, very fond of feathers and lights, has a touch screen planet-wide, with built in internet). I don't know why but I can picture Mrs. Eywa knitting very bright colored sweaters. When Gaia intervenes it does not intervene gracefully or subtly. Great number of assorted colors of claws, jaws and horns settle the score. Ecological message, "do not bomb the mother nature, she bites"Political message "our foreign policy won't change soon" Mineralogical message "unobtainium does grow on trees" Military message "use ballistic missiles, drop something from orbit, do not catch arrows"Possible Na'vi extinction cause "headache, tailache and combinations"Conclusion "If your new bride is blue, just borrow some unobtainium".

In some ways this movie is trying to be an adult version of Ferngully the last rainforest. The part of the world inhabited by these creatures, the 'moldy h icans' is like a director's wet dream of Eden, only with attractively plant draped mountains that float (instead of bolting into space). Meanwhile the inhabitants are a wide range of large or stretched versions of creatures we are familiar with: Big big bugs or flying reptiles.It is a concept flick- man through technology transmits mind into fabricated creature that can live among the intelligent kind of its homeworld. The homeworld has something we (evil humans) want. Humans cannot live on planet but we want a precious material which defies gravity, baldly called unobtainium. The aliens are blue, and look (pick one) like elongated supermodels (every one of them) or cat people with no fur or whiskers. Either way you get wide faces and big yellow eyes right off those 70s paintings on black velvet only with pouty lips. One possibly somewhat original idea is that the intelligent social aliens have tails, at the end of which are exposed nerve fibers that can bond with significantly useful critters to ride, such as a reptilian eyed large flyer, or other critters where the nerve endings might come from other parts of their bodies like a tail to head mind-meld.I do not recall any of these sharp toothed creatures eating or any significant blood flow from anything. Even the roots of the trees are nerve endings according to the Sigourney Weaver character. Meanwhile, there are no latrines, these natives apparently wander around the vertical environment making nerve contact with wondrous beings but don't need to eat, defecate, raise children, set broken bones, sign contracts, clear leafmold, or establish a government. They don't apparently make music unless they are all arrayed in a large pattern helping the roots save someone's life or convert them to alienhood. It's like woodstock without the rain, the mud, or for that matter, the music. The movie soundtrack was by James Horner who seemed to channel tangerine dream at times, and John Williams at other times. So sometimes the music was spacy, and other times it was star wars.It goes on for 2 and a half hours and is excruciatingly unbelievable on its own terms. More than the ten bucks, it's the 2 and a half hours I'll never get back and the pained look I could feel on my face as the bad guys were made to look really bad, driving bulldozers ten stories high or trying to destroy an especially important part of the fiber tree of life.If you loved the self-righteous extermination of the environment to make a point such as "On Dangerous Ground" where the good guys blow up an arctic oil refinery in order to promote environmentalism, this film may resonate with you.Personally, I think putting the ten dollars to a meal with a lot of fiber in it would have had more agreeable results with a better end product.

Avatar is a lame fairy tale, boring and cringe-worthy, that will appeal only to those who are gullible and easily taken in by an attempt to be fantastical. I love movies and sadly, this one not only bored me to tears but sitting through it was sheer torture, nothing less. And this from James Cameron, whose Terminator and Titanic are my two favorite movies of all time and whose many other films i have seen, loved and admired. The great Sigourney Weaver, who is a class act, delivers a serviceable performance at most. Sam Worthington fares better, although one wishes at times that he had a little more of the charisma of a Leo DiCaprio or a Johnny Depp. Then there is the villain Col Quaritch who is so cartoonish he might have come straight from the pages of a comic book. The biggest tragedy of Avatar is that after all the years and money invested, the final product is so insipid, unoriginal and uninspiring. The music score doesn't come anywhere near John Barry's Dances With Wolves or James Horner's Titanic. And what is most scary is when Hollywood starts making crap movies like this, there is no hope left for mankind.

So here goes another "action thriller" movie which is like any other run-of-the-mill variety except for its 3D sauce.A far-away planet inhabited by humanoids, who speak (accented English!!), act, walk, emote just like humans on earth, and whose land is rich in some mineral deposits - well the concept of "pandora" may be fine, its cinematography, or should I say rendering is awe-inspiring, use of 3D is innate and hence is simply mesmerizing, but without any story and character it is pure techno-porn.A battle sequence that is spiced up with motion-controlled robots and fancy looking warships controlled by eye-candy projector screens, deserves a better climax than a knife and bow-arrow fight between the main characters, particularly so when the "winner" is a no-brainer! Even as a 3D spectacle like "never-before-seen", at ~ 3 hours, even my eyes start feeling the weight of those goggles. To conclude, in my opinion, this is a movie about "How to win the love of a humanoid chick in less than 100 days" - (if you notice carefully, Jake's last video log is numbered 98!) No wonder it drags for so long...

I felt pretty embarrassed while watching this movie, like more than when I went to see Twilight or Harry Potter. The characters have African accents and features, fake native American ''culture'' including feather head-dresses and using every part of the animal, blue smurf skin and ride around on pterodactyls like Everquest. And they do drum dances to worship a tree god. like, an actual tree that is their god. literally. not as a metaphor, and not a talking tree, just a plain old burnable wooden tree that is also their god.We are clearly meant to take all this seriously, which is the really sad part: the audience was literally laughing out loud. I mean...I've written some stuff I'd be severely embarrassed to have other people read, and then other people read it, so I can relate to the writer here. I feel bad for him. but STILL.Everyone keeps saying in the other reviews how much money is involved as if that makes the movie good when to my view it makes the whole situation even more embarrassing. There is no way i could have overestimated this movie's moronicness before seeing it, yet we've mobilized massive amounts of our modern cultural capital squarely behind something that reads like everquest fanfic. I'm a little bit frightened by all the positive reviews---I'm afraid people are going to spot me and say ''you're not one of us'' and either give me a lobotomy or try to eat me.My favorite character was definitely the corporate overlord. He refers to what they seek as ''unobtainium'' which is an old Usenet/scifi word, and I chuckled because his character was so clued-in and terse in his evilness, made it fun. but then later in the movie he shouts in a serious high-action moment ''the unobtainium is underneath that rock right there!'' and then military dudes fire on the rock, or something, as if the corporate guy doesn't realize it's not actually called unobtainium. That's just a snarky stand-in word for when you're explaining a common story to someone else and want to say ''who cares what it really is,'' when of course it _is_ something specific when you're outside a moment of reflexive exposition. It's like the writer heard some clued people talking to each other, didn't really get what they were talking about but decided he wanted to be just like them, then tried to mimic them. like when a five year old tries to swear like a drunken sailor but doesn't know how to use the words right yet so he sounds all FOB-y, the movie was like that.also like i said, they have blue skin, talk like continental Africans, and ride around on pterodactyls. please don't forget that part. If you think you can handle this, whatever, go for it.

This was a lousy decade for sci-fi films and I think the 00s have claimed James Cameron, the one person I was counting on to bring back the glory days of the 80s and 90s. What happened to all the Aliens, the Terminators, the RoboCops, the Abysses, the Predators, the Total Recalls, the Jurassic Parks, even The Running Mans? Muscular sci-fi action movies that wowed us with fantastic concepts and visuals while commenting on poignant truths with wit and lack of pretense?For all those triumphs, James Cameron is my personal film-making hero. Which makes the following all the harder to say: AVATAR is Cameron's weakest film to date. Which isn't to say that it's bad... but it's bad for a James Cameron movie.First, the story is unoriginal. It's "Pocahontas", plain and simple. The Na'vi, despite being blue and 10 feet tall, are your typical chanting, dancing, Mohawk-sporting, bow-shooting, bead-wearing, body-paint-covered, "Earth-is-our-mother" whooping Indians.Just pop in a DVD of the 1995 Disney cartoon and count the similarities: Intrepid male soldier who sets off to a new world in search of danger & adventure to test himself? Check. Equally adventurous daughter of the natives' Chief that secretly spies the white soldier exploring her land, befriends him and teaches him the ways of the tribe? Check. The stiff Chief-to-be appointed suitor that the native princess shuns in favor of the white guy? Check. The ensuing fight between the two and arranged execution of the white guy? Check. The white visitors' authority who only cares about money and guns, calling the natives "savages" and launching a final confrontation under false pretenses? Check. The native princess leading the white guy to a sacred tree to ask for advice? Check. The way she then defends the white soldier from her own people as they are about to kill him? Check. Christ, I'm surprised Neytiri didn't break out into song about teaching Jake how to paint with "the colors of the wind".From what I read, Cameron first wrote this story in 1995, the year the Pocahontas movie came out. Coincidence? Either way, I've seen it all before.Second, why were the characters so under-developed? Jake and Neytiri's romance feels, at points, shoehorned to forward the plot. Their first meeting: "Why didn't you let me die?" "Because you have a strong heart." Come on, Jim, I know you can do better than that. The point at which they confess their love essentially boils down to "I choose you" "I choose you too" with none of the crafted buildup that led to Jack & Rose's first kiss on the Titanic.Trudy Chacon. What is her motivation? Why is she helping our heroes? Why is she the ONLY pilot who suddenly (and awkwardly) says "f*** it" and turns away from blasting the Na'vi tree? Does she have friends, insecurities, family? She's just a chick there to quip lines and kick ass.The bad guys are painfully one-dimensional. Quatrich is a maniac without an ounce of humanity. Think Lieutenant Coffey from "The Abyss", except without the gradual slide into madness from the anger and paranoia. Coffey cried tears before setting off the nuke and that's when you realize the guy is gone... you almost feel sorry for the man before he implodes in his crippled craft. By contrast, Quatrich is a G.I. Joe that likes to blow stuff up for the fun of it. Selfridge is equally limp: just a cardboard cutout of some tie-wearing yuppie who only cares about the bottom line. Do these guys have friends? Ideals? Outside lives? Nope, they're just there as straw men in this transparent social commentary.Which brings me to: "War on Terror", "pre-emptive strike", "shock and awe". These are words thrown out by the baddies at the finale without anyone so much as blushing, just in case there was any doubt what half the movie's commentary is about. I'm about as anti-Bush and anti-IraqWar as you can get, and these bald-faced references made me cringe. Gone is any masterful subtlety that allows the audience to piece together their own conclusions -- let's simply hammer it into their heads instead. Even Dubya himself was less simplistic than the caricatures portrayed in this movie and this kind of straw-man commentary actually works contrary to the aims of the artist because it paints a picture of someone too evil, too simple, and too unidentifiable to be compared to any kind of actual person, thus letting the real villain off the hook.I know Cameron is a better writer than this, which is what surprised and frustrated me most of all. So what happened in those 12 years? Maybe the epic battle scenes of the new "Star Wars" and "Lord of the Rings" movies gave him the foolish idea that anyone possibly empathizes with hundreds of faceless pawns getting shot and killed in massive battle scenes while our hero soldier and his beloved warrior princess emerge alive and victorious. Maybe he felt that "District 9", "Iron Man" and "Transformers" didn't amply satisfy our lust for cool CGI battle-bots sequences. Maybe his extended absence has let lesser visionaries like Peter Jackson and Michael Bay set the course for epic adventure cinema and he was merely following suit.The movie is visually stunning and another landmark achievement in effects. But the same can be said for Star Wars Episodes I - III and I don't see anyone hailing those movies as masterpieces. All in all, with AVATAR, Cameron has again become a pioneer of visual effects... but the complete opposite is true in terms of writing. He has fallen to regurgitating the tired sci-fiction/fantasy plots and concepts of this lackluster decade, forgot how to craft an organic plot and love story, and neglected to hide the marionette strings in his bold social commentary puppet show.You're still my hero, Jim. I look forward to "Battle Angel" with, for the first time, cautioned optimism.

The first thought in my head was: Are you kidding me?! The story is old and well known, predictable and childish. The technology surely is something new but I've got some simple questions: 1.Is it so hard when you make a nice technology to finish the deal with a nice plot?!?!?!(after all some really brilliant movies are in war for the audience attention and they are being judged for so many things other than effects...) 2.Are we supposed to like those ugly bluish creatures just because they seem real?! 3. Rally?No kidding? U actually believe that a naive predictable clich√© story should be called "the best movie" even though its just ridiculous: blue creatures on another planet telling us the story of Pocahontas....seriously I feel abused....

Yes, I totally agree with jerichocane-1, Avatar is a remake of Dances with Wolves, but with blue and very tall Indians.Moreover, there is question in the IMDb FEQ section that says, and I quote:"Is "Avatar" based on a book?No. Avatar is based on an original screenplay penned by writer/director/producer James Cameron".That is not exactly true. Many years ago, in a book of the "The Science Fiction Hall of Fame edited by Ben Bova, I read a story about a crippled man on a wheel chair, mentally connected to a super-being (a feline centaur in this case) who was intended to establish a colony in a very aggressive planet, unfit for human settlers. At the end, the man abandons his wasted human form to live a new, challenging life in the planet. Sounds familiar?Unfortunately, I remember neither the title nor the name of the writer.I concede that Avatar has a good creative work regarding the environment in Pandora, but the script is a bad mixture of good old stories.By the way, wasn't there also a pirate called Cameron?P.S. Well, I finally found the story. It is Poul Anderson's "Call me Joe", written in 1957.Please check the link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_Me_JoeAnd I accept that some mediocre script writers find "inspiration" in other people writings, but at least they should have the decency of giving the credit.

James Fenimore Cooper meets the 21st century. The Noble Savage theme just will not die. Here, it gets recycled into the "covert operative infiltrates enemy camp and finds out they are nobler than us and changes sides, with tragic consequences" plot line. Moreover, the bad guys are cartoonishly bad and the good guys are utterly without fault, cartoonishly noble. A good movie is one that tells us something true and challenges our understanding of ourselves, our world, our values. In this film, none of the characters has any genuine depth or is even remotely believable. While this may be OK in a mindless action movie, for a film that pretends to be "important", such failings are not forgivable. The one original part of the movie is the avatar concept. The rest is overdone, anti-Western, neo-pagan claptrap, albeit with genuinely impressive special effects. Somebody out there really knows what to do with a computer.

I was very moved by this film. I saw it as an allegory of what the whites did to the natives in North America, South America, Australia, New Zea land and Tasmania (especially there)--almost complete genocide for the sake of monetary profit by corporate magnates. And since corporations are the real power in developed countries: they have carte blanche to kill as needed. They usually are clever in creating a body of lies that help to dehumanize the victims. (Easier to kill 'em).The way to drive such a principle home, which means into the heart AND the head, is to show both sides. So we see the natives, Navi, in their culture which includes art, mythology, dance, music, and meaningful rituals. You can come to love any culture (even white European) if you are exposed to this side of humans. And in so doing, it would become horrible to wipe them out for the sake of a fat bank account back home. That is what Cameron does. He gets you on the side of the humanity, in this case, the Navi. (We already know about the dark side of homo Sapiens but it is well sketched in here by the mercenary grunts. I think DANCES WITH WOLVES tells much the same story. There the corporate element stays in the background which was OK for that film.I was like a little boy visiting a heaven-like world with "people" who were conscious of other things besides money and power. In the back of my mind I wondered that any race could be that harmonious. North American "Indians" treated other tribes horribly in most areas like on the the Plains and conducted raids and wars where there was much cruelty. (See the film THE BLACK ROBE, for a New England version of this.) Were the Navi like that? And what if they were? I guess the question is greed. Given the means would some Navi have exterminated other tribes and gotten rich? They didn't seem to need to be rich.So are all intelligent bipedal creatures alike? I once heard a theory about why there are no space travelers from beyond--if they became as intelligent as we, they'd also encounter the same jealousies and greed that we have, thus preventing them from combining their resources and cooperating--the infighting would bar them from space travel.A wonderful epic film. The love story was poetic. The creatures were beautiful and scary. So were the plants. The hero started off a klutz but grew on me. And I liked hearing Wes Studi's voice again. He was the "bad" Indian in DANCES as he was in LAST OF THE MAHICANS.

oh my god, i have seen a lot of movies, although there are still a few movies i like more than avatar, but i give avatar a perfect 10/10, and i've never given any movie a perfect score. Avatar deserve a special spot on its own, in that it is not just a movie, it's an experience, watch it in 3d and imax if you can, because you almost feel like you are there. YOU HAVE TO GO SEE IT. PERIOD. It made me depressed afterwards that i have to go back to the normal, boring life again. oh, how much i would give to live in pandora! I also like the romance in the movie, that got me kind of emotional.ps: don't wait for the DVD, don't watch it on the computer or TV, don't see it in 2d, or even 3d, but see it in IMAX 3D, and i promise you will not regret it.

OK, this is my first review but i am going to be completely honest.First of all, this movie is predictable. A handicapped marine was given a mission to get close to the clans, eventually fall in love with one of them, then became one of them. Its so predictable it took of all the excitement i had throughout the whole movie! I though it would be a great plot since the budget of this movie was so expensive, so i kept my hopes high. In the end, it ends up just as mentioned. Disappointed...Secondly, the CGIs. This can actually be an animation since almost every scene is completely in CGI. And the CGI even looked cartoon-ish. The characters looked cartoon-ish,the creatures looks cartoon-ish. The only thing I enjoyed in this movie is the scenery. (Hence the 3, it would be a 2 if it wasn't for the scenery.) It's not a bad movie actually,it's watchable. I just think with the given budget it could be just a lot better,a way lot better movie than this.

Avatar as a visual exercise is a masterpiece,however that should not distract from the terrible dialogue and boring storyline.It is an overlong and dreary rehash of a story that has been done before. The only character I could relate to was colonel Quaritch,about halfway through this funeral of a film I was hoping he'd succeed in slaughtering the blue shits and end the film. Unfortunately Its a Disney money making piece of sh-it, with hundreds of millions spent on marketing to convince the unwashed masses to put down their cheese burgers and turn off the X-factor/American idol.So the "good guys" have to win and colonel Quaritch dies(*sob*) before he can kill the human traitors and save the world. Only see this if you HAVE never seen 3D,other then that its a waste of time.

Avatar is without a doubt the worst ripoff-remake ever ,i can't believe that no one else has notice, so what do we have here?, OK let's see, the space travel, the remote unexplored world, the hibernation, the hostile extraterrestrials, the marines, the robot suits, Sigourney Weaver!!!! come on!!!! it sounds familiar to you? ....sure it is familiar, it sounds like....Aliens(1986) from James Cameron. Mr Cameron committed plagiarism but not only with his own work, the script about a soldier who betrayed his own people has nothing of new or original, it is the same premise that The last Samurai (2003) from Edward Zwick, or dances with wolves (1990) from Kevin Costner, so what's new here? only the visual effects that are in fact state of the art....Cameron let us debt after all these years since Titanic, he has no new ideas, only better special effects

Okay first off I know a lot of people love this movie and they're going to hate me for this review but its the truth that a lot of you just need to understand...Avatar was NOT very creative in any way whatsoever. Let me list the issues:A story that reminds me of Disney's Pocahontas too much. If you want to make a good movie, make the story better. If it takes you 15 years to make this thing then you need to get it right. The story needs to be much more original than that. It needs far more development and they should have more information in it for a 2.5 hour movie.Special effects that weren't actually very good, they could have done better when they spent that much money on them... The "big battle scene" at the end wasn't very big really... It had lots of explosives yes, but thats about all.The acting wasn't 5 star in any way. There were some pretty cheesy lines too. Why do we need this nonsense? If its going to be the movie we'll remember then great... But I'm not going to remember this thanks to its lack of creativity. Inception beats it, times ten.3D? Meh, overrated. Okay so 3D gets really old; I saw How to Train Your Dragon and Avatar in it. You don't even notice it after 10 minutes into the movie! 3D is overrated and definitely overpriced.

Avatar is a good movie, it's not "awesome" or "unique", and it's not even by chance "the best movie ever made" (god no). For start, I don't find the CGI or animation being important in any movie, I found the plot, OST and characters being the most important part of a movie; in those aspects:The movie had a good (but not remarkable) OST, it's good, but after 3 hours becomes tedious.The plot was good also and I liked how they represented colonialism, but did you noticed that Jake NEVER speaks to the Na'vi about the unobtainium and why they were invading them? THAT WAS YOU PRIMARY ORDER DUDE!. It also had nothing new or "revolutionary" like all the critics were saying for some reason, it's just another random Hollywood plot which looks like if it was promoted by Greenpeace.About the characters, the only good thing I found is how the Na'vi were made, they're very convincing for me, but that was the only good part. I hated the rest of the characters, about Neytiri, the movie ended and I couldn't remember her name, I think they mentioned it like 3 times in the whole movie (she was a MAIN character) and she was like a bad-ass 16 teenager or something alike that doesn't seem right for a love nature princess; the "evil" guy had no brain at all, one would think that in a future where they can create giant-blue-people-clones, they would have some kind of mental standard to choose a general who will lead an army in the space, but no. And all the "original" creatures that Camron created, they seemed like a big "Final Fantasy X" plagiarism, really, FFX has a tribe of savage-blue-giant people, has an Eidolon called Ixion who is identical to the Na'vi's horses, has dragons which seems a lot like those in the film, and has flying light balls of energy like those "jellyfish".So in conclusion, if I had to choose between watching Avatar again or playing Final Fantasy X, I would stay home and play FFX, is practically the same with a better plot and more interaction.

I'll start by saying that Avatar is a great action movie. James Cameron served notice to George Lucas and ILM that they aren't the major players in the Sci-Fi film making anymore. The action in this movie puts the Star Wars franchise to shame with the exception of The Empire Strikes Back. The final 40 minutes are a 3D CGI tour-De-force of breath-taking battles, explosions and war machines that will leave your jaw swinging in the breeze! "So much for the prince, now about the monster."- Suetonius, The Twelve Ceasars, in reference to Caligula.Ever wonder what would happen if you put the cartoon: "Smurfs", script elements of the Space Marines from "Aliens", the Broadway play, "Cats", Richard Dreyfus's character from "Whose Life Is It Anyway", and the hollow tree from the Keebler cookie commercials, and tossed the lot into a blender? Well, you would get "Avatar"! This is probably the most half-assed, lazy script in Sci-Fi I have seen; clich√©d and over wrought with cardboard characters, a five year old on cough syrup could have written better. Let's delve into why, shall we? Poor Jake Sully! He's a paraplegic who has lived in the shadow of his more talented brother; a scientist in a military operation that gets killed in a robbery. The military perceives Jake as a F___up, irresponsible, childish, not military material, unlike his more popular, deceased brother. So for whatever reason(I know; he's gonna use the money to buy legs) the military decides to place him in the Avatar project his brother worked on. WHY? No one believes he can do anything productive in it, even head scientist Augustine thinks he's unsuitable initially. Jake Sully is depressed and trying to find a place in a world that doesn't need a cripple. (Whose Life Is It Anyway?!) At this point forward, things get stupid and kooky.See, the Earth needs a mineral called "Unobtanaium" that will save humanity from some misfortune; the point is laid out out by a greedy lil' executive lifted directly from the "Aliens" script. And the only place to get it is from Pandora, and its sentient race, the Na'vi(Smurfs, 10 ft tall ones with prehensile tails)don't know where its located. Cameron probably gave the script to one of his children at this time because the idiocy just piles up like a stack of pancakes. You see, if your planet needs some valuable mineral to save humanity, the last thing you do is put Gomer Pyle on your team, and while objections abound toward allowing Sully on board, no one in a MILITARY OPERATION stops him. My temples were throbbing at this point. They'll explode later! Everything else, you see coming from a country mile! Sully digs getting to walk with his new avatar body and proceeds to screw the project up. He isn't supposed to get too cozy with the Na'vi, yet does anyway. Falls in love, etc. But, of course! He doesn't fit in with the humans in the program; he is rolling in the fantasy of being something that he isn't. We know it won't take long for him to fall in love with his new body- he's a paraplegic. It's an obvious plot point. That's what I mean by Cameron's script being a heap of laziness. He doesn't even try to be creative, just derivative. He robs his movies and other works and hammers them together even though they don't mesh, and he doesn't care if you notice.The vistas are ripped off from old YES album covers(artist Roger Dean), Sully has a fall from grace after falling for Neytiri, daughter of the clan chief. Natch- its always a princess! The head of the project is an crusty, hard core Marine who only wants to wipe the Na'vi out because they are in the way of his mission. You know he's going to try to decimate them after he talks for 2 minutes. The Na'vi have been compared to the Smurfs, but they are more like an off-Broadway production of Cats; look closely. There's even a mythical beast that only Sully can tame, which he uses on the Marines. Of course! Then, there's Hometree(Keebler elves and their hollow magical tree). So, all the unobtanium is conveniently located under the most sacred thing in the Na'vi's lives- how effing obvious! On the whole of Pandora, there is just one Hometree, but the Na'vi are spread like peanut butter across the planet- WHY? And why is a mineral only under a tree, and one tree at that? I do remember my HS geology, shouldn't old plant material be like oil? The Na'vi have no idea that its the mineral the humans are after, why not just mine it out from under them? Guess because we would be deprived of some excellent action at the near end of the movie. It's like "Titanic", really. You revel in the carnage as the Na'vi's tree is toppled. And of course, our hero gets to keep his new body and live happily ever after.This is a bubble gum movie, nothing more. It has no real depth, no honesty, no meaning; save that war is the answer to a mineral shortage. But the make believe world is awesome; maybe thats enough to redeem it. But to be honest, I can't sit through another viewing of the thing. It makes your mind go numb. Do yourself a favor, watch "The Terminator", or "Aliens" again. This movie will go stale on you fast!

I was very impressed with the effects. They were wonderful. Ultimately, however, the storyline was utterly predictable. The emotions shown were overly maudlin and the characters were two dimensional. Were it not for the special effects, after the first 20 minutes one would be better off simply imagining the rest. While it has been claimed that the movie's message is "anti-business", it is really another rehashing of the "Noble Primitive" tale, an idea which Hollywood has done to death. It seems somehow ironic that it was done using millions of dollars with cutting edge technology to create a futuristic science fiction movie. Or, if its message really is a warning against the evils of big business, it certainly has made a lot of money. I give it 5 stars for the special effects, because they almost make it worth watching.

If I described the plot of this to someone who had no idea that the movie had crazy special effects, they'd say that it sounds predictable. Well it is. It has one of the worst villains I've ever seen in a movie and every plot point is clich√© and uninspired. Although if the movie had ended with the tree being destroyed and the Navi losing, I would've loved it. The Navi paralleled American Indians until the ended when they won, which ruined the whole point of making them reminiscent of Indians. If they had committed to that and given it a sad ending, the movie would've actually had a message instead of characters just constantly saying that "we destroyed our earth" and stuff like that. And the only the movie is the highest grossing movie ever is because it's in 3d, which adds $3 to every ticket sold.

People can spout how wonderful James Cameron's genius is when it comes to making huge, expensive and successful films, that isn't too hard to debate. But to say this film is original in any way is a bit of a stretch. Anyone who has watched Star Trek, Farscape, StarGate, and other sci fi films and series know that the storyline is NOT new. Granted, the special effects have come a long way from years ago and it shows in how much money and time he has put into the film. What I have to love is the fact that for all the hype and speculation for Academy nominations, everyone EXPECTED AVATAR to win. . .and it didn't. His first ex-wife won with her film about a real life subject and way under a fraction of the amount Cameron spent. The Gods have a good sense of humor to be sure. :-)

Yes this is 'Science Fiction', but the intended relationships with the elements of reality were so poor that they grated on my nerves throughout. Very clever CGI. Lovely colours. Sexy aliens. Characters absolutely unsympathetic. I couldn't develop any empathy at all with who they were or what they were doing. Any of them.The military staff were portrayed as the worst kind of gung-ho 'shoot-em- ups', full of prejudice against the natives of the land they have invaded so that they can steal the resources. The director couldn't have been less subtle in taking a swipe at Americans and America's foreign policies. Unintelligent. Was the film intended for an audience so self-centred and insulated from the world that the message needed to be force-fed at the expense of the final quality of the film?

There are so many things wrong with this movie I don't even know where to begin. I know it's been months since the release but I have to get this off my chest. To refresh my memories I fast-forwarded the movie in HD and... what an overrated piece of crap. The negative reviews are right - exclude the CGI and you're left with nothing. On the same note the CGI is not even that great. They've spent $500 million on this but guess what, the CG characters still look fake. Hell even the real ones look fake. I've seen more believable CG characters: I Robot, District 9, Watchmen, King Kong... Anyways, let me try to break this down: 1. First of all let's take a look at the story. We all know what it is so I'm not going to summarize it. Cameron had 13 years and half a billion dollars at his disposal and yet he FAILED to come up with a decent plot. The story is cheap, predictable, the script is full of clich√©s of all kinds and it's copied from a bunch of other sources. It's so banal it's not even worth telling your kids as a bedtime story. You're probably thinking "this guy has the nerve to use the word 'story'...?". I admit that IS wrong.2. Characters. Let's face it, every character in this movie is the very definition of the word stereotype. You've got this slow marine, some geeky scientists, a tough woman lead scientist, a greedy corporate guy, a bad-ass military guy, a fragile forbidden female for the marine to fall for, her father he has to impress... Anything you can think of that isn't original - you've got it here. This literally forces you to not care about any of them throughout the whole movie. I know what you're thinking, you're thinking "this guy has the nerve to use the word 'character'...?".3. Jake Sully is the main character. Cameron knew his movie was going to suck, so he made the main character double crippled in an attempt to make you care about him. Jake Sully is a slow paraplegic ex-marine. Every sentence he comes up with sounds as if written by a 5 year old. The following scene literally proves my point. OK, so Neytiri, the beautiful and fragile aborigine girl saves Jake from the dangers of the forest and takes him to her tribe, the elders gather and mumble about something, Jake asks "what are they talking about", Neytiri says "my father is deciding whether to kill you". If it were you you'd probably go "oh shoot, they want to kill me, what do I do". But not Jake, he's smarter than that, he's thinking with his dong. What Jake does, he stretches out his hand and says "oh you're the father, nice to meet you sir". You're surrounded by a tribe of savage aliens that openly want to kill you, they don't speak a word of English and this is the best you can come up with to protect your skin? What a retard!4. Music really sucks. All that new world / ethnic crap... come on!5. The whole concept of Pandora is ridiculous to say the least. Remember, this is a moon some 6 light years away from Earth, and yet everything is the same. Humans biologically have more things in common with the Naaaaviiii from 6 light years away than with any other creature on Earth. Genius!5.1. Pandora is a moon and from the shots Cameron shows us we see that the planet it's orbiting is actually very big. The events take place during quite a long period of time and yet we never see a solar eclipse. Makes you wonder how the hell is Pandora orbiting it's planet so that these people over a period of a few years never witness a simple solar eclipse. I'll tell you why it never happens in the movie. If an eclipse took place on Pandora, even if it were for just a few days, no creature would possibly survive on that piece of rock. Cameron couldn't have that in the movie without backing it up with some more sci-fi stuff, but you can't really blame the guy, he had only 13 years to think this through! 5.2. Everything is the same. The creatures, the primate Naaavii, vegetation, landscape, waterfalls, sky etc. Humans can't survive on Pandora without an oxygen mask, meaning the atmosphere has to consist of something else, doesn't this also mean that the sky has to have a different color? Too complicated for the average moviegoer?5.3. At some point in the movie the oh so bad-ass colonel Quaritch says the low gravity can make your muscles soft, that's why he goes to the gym. And yet, as they move around, as Ribisi is playing golf, you never actually see motion being affected by low gravity. Remember the moon landing footage? See what I mean? Too complicated?5.4. My final point - Pandora is 6 freaking light years away! Cameron had every opportunity to make it look different, unusual, interesting and awesome. But he didn't. Instead he made it look exactly like Earth. Pandora might as well be some remote place here on Earth.What a waste of time, at least I'm glad I didn't pay to see this crap. Awful movies are being made all the time, what sickens me is the positive ratings Avatar is getting and all the facts surrounding it, the budget for one. Wouldn't it be more rewarding, for example, to instead feed and clothe the poor with that money. No, let's instead fill our minds with banal garbage. Avatar makes me feel political, and I am never political and I hate this movie for it.

So I was watching the movie because of all the rave reviews about it, and man was i in for quite an unpleasant surprise. After the first 15 min my mind started to daydream about going to see a better movie to watch...then went further into the movie, contemplated watching wolfman and started imagining myself watching it. Then it came to all the action scenes or whatever and i just didn't feel the blue skin people thing. It was soooooooo unreal and just didn't capture my attention it reminded me of an intermediate computer project on film. I could not wait to get the hell out of there watching or trying to watch this crap of film...

How does James Cameron do it? How does he manage to take a hokey, transparent story and make it work? It is amazing. Just like with Titanic, Mr. Cameron creates a great movie out of an old story. The movie is great because it grabs and keeps the audience's interest. Also, Mr. Cameron takes CGI to a new level of sophistication, so much so that soon the CGI and the real acting merge as one ... and it works! Having expected this movie to be little more than a long cartoon, surprisingly the movie is a work of cinematic art, and not just an animated feature with voice overs added. The cast is superb, especially Stephen Lang, who plays perhaps the most challenging role, and the always lovely Michelle Rodriguez who gives a strong performance as a soldier with a heart. If this movie proves anything, it is that Michelle Rodriguez is one of the finest actors in Hollywood today, and beautiful too.

The message behind Avatar is a noble one, but that doesn't go far enough to cover up the unimaginative storyline and dialogue. Avatar is heavy on clich√©s that we've seen plenty of times before: Hero goes to a strange land and isn't accepted by the natives. Fast forward 45 minutes and he's finally been accepted into their inner circle. Inevitably he will find someone there that he falls in love with at first sight. Their love will be endangered by the enemy that seeks to harm the natives in some way or other. And so on and so on. You can pretty much predict everything that's going to happen within the first 20 minutes, which is remarkable considering the running time is well past 2 and half hours.I give it a 5/10 based solely on it's visual merits and recognition for the amount of effort it takes to put something on this large of a scale together. That in itself is admirable. I just wish that there was actually some substance to back the film up.

I will do an experiment review now: I will try to compare this movie to a woman.You catch a glimpse of her and you fall in love. You approach her, she gets prettier with every step you take towards her. Her smile blinds you and her eyes captivate you. You're drowning in her, deeper and deeper. Then you start a conversation with her, try to get to know her better. You notice that she talks simple, sometimes to the point of being unwise. The topics she chooses are boring and shallow and her attempts at jokes are not funny.Now you know.She is a girl from the poster. Perfect in every way but only in a still frame.

Frankly, I was underwhelmed. The plot is derivative: "Ferngully" out of "The Matrix" by the Pilot episode of "Star Trek"; Cameron is so awed by the wonderful canvas he's painting (and it Is visually stunning) that he forgets about developing such things as a story. The romance is predictable - so predictable, in fact that he neglects any foreplay. We all know what's coming, anyway, so why bother? The bad guy is Saturday Matin√©e Evil, our hero's introduction to the clan is Way too easy (he's accepted with only a token argument; the rest of it is about his "Manhood Training"), and the Climax is Exactly what you'd expect from a formula that says Good must fight Evil by being Just as Bad***, in addition to being made of Rubber and Luckier.On the Plus side, the music by Horner is nice, though reminiscent of "Titanic" in spots, and the Palette IS absolutely Awesome. It's Almost worth the price of admission as an Art Exhibit. I gave it almost every star I did because of the scenery. Without it I would have been hard pressed to come up with one.Which is why, if you're going to see it, you really should spend the extra to see it in 3D.All the way through I kept hoping that Cameron would at least produce an ending worthy of the great art work. Perhaps the spiritual energy of the planet would mass itself and produce an energy field that made the weapons of the baddies useless. It would have shown that Good really Is stronger than Evil. After all, I kept saying to myself, he Did hang the idea that the entire planet is one organism on the wall (Its an old theatrical maxim: if you hang it on the wall in the 1st act, you better be prepared to use it in the 3rd). He Should do Something with it.I should have known better. Nobody would go to see it. Absolutely No Box Office appeal in non-violence. The teen age males among us (chronologically or emotionally) got their money's worth. it's got some "Transformers" in it, too.

We All know that Cameron is a genius. The man ha made some consistently fantastic films since 1984. 12 years after the behemoth which was 'Titanic', he gives us Avatar.It's mixed bag unfortunately, and it's as if Cameron has borrowed from some of his other movies just to get a head start in the story arc.The obvious movies he has borrowed from are the Abyss and Aliens, with their discovering life/war connotation respectively, and Cameron keeps with the protection of the loved one/parental instinct issues he has used in his movies since 'The Terminator, which is all good stuff, but after all the hype and the trailer, the film is decidedly more 'okay' than awe-inspiring.the effects may be the best i have seen on screen, and the 3-D really adds a whole new life to the movie. Cameron knows how to make a spectacle, and the last 45 minutes of the movie are probably the most amazing thing you will see on the big screen for a while (and i mean big screen, there are a lot of films with better endings, but for pure spectacle, you have to hand it to Cameron).the cast are good, Worthington again proves that he could be the next big thing for a while, and the rest of the crew are solid. but the poor film suffers from the hype button being pressed too hard for too long.i was expecting something that not only would change the ways movies are made (i know thats asking a lot), but would deliver a solid story and character development, with good narration.all the technical stuff is absolutely spot on, and it will no doubt win awards for effects, editing, sound and so on. but the narration and the script were in desperate need of tweaking.at times i wondered whether i was watching a film by an egotist gone mad, a work of art, the smurf movie or the most expensive sci-fi ever made.time will tell.a good film, but just over-hyped too much.

This whole movie is just Pocahontas in space. In fact, let's take a look at the plot summaries for the two movies; (Male protagonist) leads a rag-tag band of (soldiers) to the New World to plunder its riches for (Male protagonist's homeland) - or, more precisely, for (Male antagonist), who comes along for the ride. Meanwhile, in this "New World," (Native Chief) has pledged his daughter, (Female protagonist), to be married to the village's greatest warrior. (Female protagonist), however, has other ideas. She has seen a vision... a vision she believes tells her change is coming. Her life does indeed change when the (space)ship lands near her village. Between (Male antagonist), who believes the "savages" are hiding the (rare, valuable substance) he expected to be plentiful, and (Native Chief), who believes these newcomers will destroy their land, (Male protagonist) and (Female protagonist) have a difficult time preventing all-out war, and saving their love for each other.Granted, it's better than Colin Ferrell's 'The New World,' but why do we need another retelling of Pocahontas? We don't. But everyone will lap it up anyway.

Yes, I was able to see an advanced screening of James Cameron's long awaited science fiction film, Avatar.So, what's good about it? The visuals are among the best ever seen, the planet Pandora truly comes alive, and the creatures, wildlife, etc. All look fabulous on the big screen.What's bad about it? Cameron's trademark lame dialog is back, as well as his less than ordinary scriptwriting. The characters, with the exception of Signorey Weaver's scientist character, and Stephen Lang's Colonel Quarritch all feel wooden. The hero doesn't feel alive, he feels generic, and I felt the bad guys "humans" were cardboard caricatures. Not to mention the story is far from original. It's basically Dances With Wolves/ Pocahontas meets Aliens.What's the story about? (SPOILERS AHEAD!) In the future, Marine soldier, Jake Sully, (Played by Austrailian Sam Worthtington) is a paralyzed veteran, whose twin scientist brother was killed. The Resources Development Association, a greedy energy corporation, similar to the one used in Cameron's Aliens film gives him an opportunity to take his brother's place in the Avatar program designed by the RDA to infiltrate the natives of Pandora called the Navi, who stand ten feet tall, have blueish skin and act like Native Americans, plus they speak English. (What a surprise!) The RDA have brought in a group of marines led by the evil Colonel Miles Quarrich, easily the most interesting character of the entire film, to make sure that the Navi are displaced from their home so that the RDA can extract a mineral called "Unobtainium", which is worth $20,000,000 an ounce, since the Earth is in an energy crisis. The film has some of the greatest visuals ever recorded on film, but after a while your eyes can get a little exhausted from seeing every little detail in 3D. After Jake's introduction to the Navi by "driving" his Avatar body, the film slows down as Jake and his new found love, Neitri, played by Zoe Saldana, fall in love, and Jake discovers how the Navi tribe works. But, time is running short, Quaritch and the RDA want to displace the Navi, by force if necessary, to mine the unobtainium from the Navi grounds.The ending involves marine equipment of every sort, gunships, robotic suits, etc, all while the Navi face them down with flying dragons, dinosaurs, bows, arrows, etc. It's one of the grandest visual effects scenes ever put on film.All in all, how did I feel about this film? Well, it's certainly an improvement over Cameron's previous entry Titanic, but his clunky dialog, and shoddy storytelling are still present, and most of the characters really aren't fleshed out very well. Worthington's Sully doesn't really feel alive, Saldana's Neitri is basically Sully's Navi love interest with little to do. Giovani Ribisi's greedy corporate shrill, Parker Selfride, is a whiny irritant, and Michelle Rodriquez, plays a sympathetic marine pilot who does little in the film. Only Weaver's Dr. Grace Augustine and Stephen Lang's Quarritch stand out among the crowd. Where Cameron succeeds is in the technical aspects of the film, the visuals, by Peter Jackson's effects company WETA digital, are first rate. Also, most of the action feels unoriginal since we have seen a lot of this material in Cameron's far superior Aliens film. Plus, it never even comes close to reaching the heights of his best film, 1991's Terminator 2 Judgement Day. Plus as I said earlier the dialoge is borderline retarded, hearing lines out of Quaritch's mouth is so bad, I was hoping for some cotton balls for my ears every time I heard one of his annoying speeches. Not to mention the logical thing for the RDA to have done was to negotiate with the Navi for the unobtainium instead of taking it by force, but then again, Cameron doesn't want to use logic, he sees corporations as the ultimate evil. Very little gray in this film. The RDA is evil and the Navi are good, end of story.Would I see this again? Maybe, maybe not, but the slower aspects of the film and some of the dialog are very irritating to listen to. My wife actually got a migraine headache from wearing those 3D glasses for over two and a half hours.To sum it all up, the visuals shine, the story lags, and the dialog is awful.Avatar is not bad, but not great either. I would say it's average.

Visually stimulating, sure. But the most unoriginal plot I've seen in years, not at all creative. Not worthy of the James Cameron label. Unfortunately, I don't see why so many people have gone crazy over this film. Obviously, they were stunned to retardation by all the shiny visuals and brightly colored landscapes in the movie to the point of not realizing that they had seen this exact plot a million times over. There is nothing original in this movie, no creativity in the plot, no in-depth thought or great work of art. It is visually stimulating, and much like a blonde chasing a shiny thing around a room, it is dull and dumb to anyone who has more than 2 brain cells.

The first twenty minutes, although we're quickly force-fed the plot of a crippled marine going to a planet called Pandora where his counterpart "Avatar", clone to the indigenous natives, will seek trust in these tall blue Na'vi (all this happening while he, in human form, lays a tanning booth and guides the creature) in order to abduct a mineral to take back to earth (symbolizing oil, of course)... isn't bad, seeming as if a young James Cameron, who directed "Aliens", "The Terminator" and "The Terminator 2" with flowing precision, is at the helm. We're on a terrific adventure and it looks pretty neat. But then something happens. Once within the forest, separated from his fellow troops, the Avatar discovers he digs the peace-loving natives more the banal humans, falls in love with the hottest of the tall blue elf-folk, and after taming a flying dragon and bedding down the babe, he's "one of the gang" way too quickly. Most of the action of the film's first half, pitting our hero against forest-dwelling predators, is (in a visual and directorial sense) straight out of JURASSIC PARK; the thrills eventually taking a backseat to drawn-out new-age ceremonies and cheesy dialog too horrible to repeat. And when the big battle ensues: The Honest Natives Vs. The Greedy Americans (of course there are a few good Americans, not including the director) - the hollowly undeveloped characters get lost within the expensive flash. AVATAR, filmed in 3D but with 1D everything else, in trying to blend science-fiction, fantasy, romance, and a big bright moral message, ends up mirroring Cameron's view of the American Military: overwrought, overpriced and completely brain-dead.

I have noticed a lot of critical comments on this movie come from conservatives who dislike its allegedly "liberal" message. Let me say, first off, I am very politically liberal and progressive, consider myself an environmentalist and certainly abhor racism, and I really disliked this movie.The story is simply idiotic.Are we supposed to believe that it is commercially viable to send a massive spaceship -- that must literally cost more than the entire world's 2010 GDP to develop, build, and operate -- on a 12-year round-trip mission to Pandora just to bring back "unobtanium"? How does "the corporation" know there will be a market for it when they bring it back? If humanity has developed the technology to efficiently power a huge manned spacecraft over light-years nearly at the speed of light, then something tells me humanity can solve its energy problems (or whatever else it may be) without "unobtanium." The whole Avatar concept is underdeveloped and compares unfavorably with the similar concepts in the Matrix. Why is it that an "avatar" made of a mixture of human and Navi DNA is still an exact physical duplicate of the Navi? Shouldn't it look like a weird hybrid like the creature in "Splice"? How is it that the avatars cannot think or act for themselves? Aren't they living creatures? Don't they have their own brains? If not, how can they stay alive? Are we supposed to believe that this alien species on Pandora just happens to be close enough physically to humans that we can find them sexually attractive (as Jake does Neytiri)? The Navi just happen to have two eyes, and a nose, and a mouth with teeth like ours, and ears, and hair, and breasts, and legs, feet with toes, etc. etc. They are physically capable of speaking English, amazingly enough. Despite being aliens from another planet, they are far more similar to humans than our closest ape relatives on earth. And of course they all have washboard tummies and the woman have breasts just covered by their necklaces.Does the Navi society have to be a mishmash of every stereotype white Americans have about African/aboriginal/Native American culture? Do they have to be shown apologizing to animals they hunt and kill? (Does it really matter to a creature if you apologize to it after killing it?) Do the actors portraying the Navi tribes people have to all be of either African or American Indian descent? Do they have to speak English with either "African" or "Indian" accents and inflections? Does the tribe have to have a male "king" and a female "spiritual leader"? Does Jake's love interest have to be a "princess"? Does he have to be confronted by an angry "warrior" rival for her affections, who he ultimately wins over? Does the tribe really have to worship a big tree? Does the tree really have to be on top of the biggest cache of "unobtanium" on the planet? Are we really expected to believe that if the military decided to declare all out war on the Navi that it would lose? That spears and animals could defeat humans who had the technology portrayed in this movie? Avatar is an insult to the thinking moviegoer, even more than Titanic was. Most of these logical flaws could be overlooked if it didn't take itself so seriously. That was the saving grace of the original 1977 Star Wars -- it took itself just seriously enough, but was able to wink at itself too. And it had a lot of wit and humor, which are sorely lacking in Avatar. James Cameron clearly believes that Avatar is the greatest movie ever made. He might not admit it in interviews, but it is painfully obvious he thinks so.He could hardly be more wrong.

Anyone who comments, publicly and with scorn, that Avatar's plot line is "simple" or "hackneyed" does so at his or her peril.There are several constructs in virtually ANY form of artistic expression that almost always work: the "Fish Out of Water" the "Faust Story" and, of course, the "Reluctant Conquering Hero" being three of them that spring to mind. How many times you have seen these "overused" story and plot lines in evidence matters not. It's human nature to cotton to them (and we're talking human nature from the birth or recorded history, now) and it's the way they are carried out that determines the success of a given project. Did you like the "Matrix" films? The "Star Wars" films? What about Frodo and his friends overcoming insurmountable odds and defeating the evil Sauron? There's your "Reluctant Conquering Hero" in spades. How about "Dances With Wolves" or the "Back to the Future" movies? "Fish Out of Water". And how's about any movie where the character gets more than what he or she bargained for? Your "Faust" story. Yes, the simple fact is "Avatar" displays, and rather well I believe, all three of these themes. After his identical twin brother is killed, Corporal Jake Sully, a Marine who's been wounded and has lost the use of his legs, is sent to the lush moon, Pandora, and recruited into a mission meant to ease a group of indigenous creatures, The Na'Vi, out of an area that greedy human corporatists covet for its considerable mineral wealth. He's seduced into taking up the challenge by a blood-thirsty military commander, Colonel Miles Quaritch, who promises, in Faustian fashion, that he'll arrange for a surgical procedure necessary for Sully to regain the use of his legs IF he reports back on the Na'Vi's vulnerabilities. Sully agrees and becomes part of a program, which installs his human consciousness into a Na'Vi body, making it possible for his "Avatar" to move about freely (without the use of a portable breathing apparatus) on the planet's oxygen-poor surface. During an initial expedition, Sully becomes separated from his group and is left behind. During the night, he meets a NA'Vi princess, Neytiri, who saves him from a pack of wild dog-like creatures. She scolds him for his oafishness and takes him to her people who, because she has seen "a sign" sent from the NA'Vi's sacred "Tree of Souls", allow him to live amongst them and learn their ways. With each ensuing trip, Sully's "Fish Out of Water" becomes better acquainted with the way of the NA'Vi and, finally, he takes their side in the growing conflict. This, of course, infuriates the Colonel, ignites the ire of the mining company, and all bets are off.What happens next, yes, is somewhat predictable. You know the NA'Vi, under Sully's formerly reluctant "conquering hero" will be triumphant. You know the bad guy will be vanquished and the mining company sent packing. But, I argue, these are things we WANT to see as human beings and why these devices and themes are used over and over (and over) again. They WORK. So, it's "all been done before". So what? Clich√©s betray honest and universal truths. This is why they are used so often and why they exist, sublimely, as clich√©s.This film, for all its time-tested, ironclad plot devices, is absolutely astonishing in its newness. We've never seen anything like this planet or its inhabitants, humanoid or otherwise. The visuals are magnificent as one might expect, but it's the interaction between the NA'Vi and Sully and his resulting transformation that are at the core of the film's success. I was amazed by how moved I was by this "simple" story, by the kindness and nobility of the NA'Vi and their connection with their land. James Cameron has borrowed some not-so- simple, current real-life human themes and placed them in what is a very timely story, much in the same tradition as great TV science fiction, such as Star Trek TOS and its offspring.That $300 to $500 million was spent to bring this film to life means little as the film will more than make back its money and every single cent is up there on the screen.I just wish would-be movie snobs would shut the hell up about their having "seen this all before".The simple fact is, they haven't.
